div1.p: Leake requests information about Henry Rose Carter. Leake is assisting Hench in collecting material for his book.

div1.head: Letter from James P. Leake to Henry Rose Carter, Jr., December 10, 1946 [Enclosed in C0407001]
div1.opener:
DIVISION OF INFECTIOUS DISEASES
FEDERAL SECURITY AGENCY
U. S. PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF HEALTH
BETHESDA, MARYLAND
December 10, 1946
Dr. Henry Rose Carter, Jr.
Woodward Building,
Birmingham, Alabama
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I have just received a letter from Dr. Philip S. Hench, a professor
of medicine at Rochester and one of the owners of the Mayo Clinic, - and
have conferred about it by phone this morning with your good friend
Louis L. Williams, Jr., who as you may know is happily engaged in the
State Department in straightening out international health matters.

Dr. Hench is writing a book on the work of Walter Reed and his associ-
ates. You may have noticed that it was Hench who stimulated General Truby
(recently in command at the Army Medical Center) to write his recently
published book on recollections of the 1900 investigational days in Cuba.
Hench writes that the Reed family and the Lazear family have made him the
repository of all their letters, etc. - he had dinner with General Reed
and his sister last week, also visited Mrs. Walter Reed (aged 90) at
Blue Ridge Summit, also Mrs. G. O. Gawne, a first cousin of Dr. Lazear.
He had previously visited Lazear's widow who died in February, and during
the summer of 1946, Lazear's son and daughters in California. His industry
of that sort seems indefatigable, and it occurs to Louis Williams and my-
self that this may be an opportunity to get the whole thing straight in a
way that would have pleased your father. What do you think of it?

I know that one of the objects of your father in not publicizing to
a greater extent his own work was that no detraction in the slightest
should result toward the work of his good friend Walter Reed.

Louis has told me that you have the presentation copy of the official
Cuban book on Finlay edited by Juan Guiteras with your father's pencilled
notes in the margin stating that your father carried the crucial mosquitoes
(or eggs or larvae) from Finlay to Lazear or Reed. And it is my impression
that if it had not been for your father there would have been no cooperation
between Finlay and Reed.

If you do think well of the scheme and would be good enough to let me
borrow this book-and any other matter that you would think pertinent to
the general subject-I would have them photographed promptly for preserva-
tion of copies in the Public Health Service files, send copies to Dr.
Hench, and return the originals, with copies, to you. I also have copies
- 2 -
of a letter which Walter Reed wrote to your father, and some other notes
which I would be glad to send you if you would like to have them. I have
hunted in vain through the Army Medical Library for your father's original
manuscript which he deposited there. It is lost.

Hench believes, and it seems right, that he has discovered the site
of the original Camp Lazear near Havana, which was not the site marked
by the Cuban government. He wants to preserve the building No.1 which
he thinks he has identified and to erect a small museum over it, by 1950.
div1.closer:
With best regards,
Sincerely, James P. Leake James P. Leake
Medical Director (Retired)
U.S. Public Health Service
JPL/msb
